title: Before 1 January 2020, will Tesla release an Autopilot feature designed to navigate traffic lights?
preds: Not enough as of yet to confirm if this is even possible.
Dropping a few points to zero because there's only a few weeks left in the year.
It's too late in the year and the technology is too unproven to reliably market as an option for public consumption.

Before 1 January 2020, will Tesla release an Autopilot feature designed to navigate traffic lights?
The focus is on Shanghai as that is where profitability lies.

Before 1 January 2020, will Tesla release an Autopilot feature designed to navigate traffic lights?
Decrement 1 for each week of December.
 "Early Access Release" is a fancy term for Beta Test which by definition is not a product release, but a structured test period for select vehicles in the real world.

Before 1 January 2020, will Tesla release an Autopilot feature designed to navigate traffic lights? Scoring this one is critical.
My concern here is the definition of the word "RELEAESE". Beta testing should not count as a release of a product, by definition its still being tested. 
From Fortune:
“While it's going to be tight,” Musk said, “It still does appear that we will be . . . in early access release of a feature-complete Full Self-Driving feature this year.”
Before 1 January 2020, will Tesla release an Autopilot feature designed to navigate traffic lights? Nothing mentioned at the LA Auto Show to my knowledge.
Shifting down a few points for passage of time.

It’s a whole new form of technology, so I think it will take more time, and would prefer that it did and was not rushed. Any incident that happens in the consumer version of this technology puts the industry as a whole one step back in terms of public trust (regardless of how much safer autopilot would be compared to regular driving). I’m sure the company wants the tech to be absolutely as perfect as possible before rolling it out. Releasing that tech in less than 4 months does not seem likely at all.

Get profitable by signing every tenth expense report, build out factories on two continents, keep relevant in consumers eyes. Tesla asserted in its recent release notes in Mar 2019 that they were still in test mode for an Autosteer Stop Light Warning- which is not intended to replace a fully-attentive driver. It is only designed to make the driving experience easier.  This is far from full autonomy.  Tesla autopilot cars have to first safely navigate within and around other traffic first before they can focus attention on navigating traffic lights- and this goes beyond merely stopping at them.  Musk himself in an April 2019 interview estimated that by the middle of 2020, Tesla’s autonomous system will have improved to the point where drivers will not have to pay attention to the road.  At this investors event, Musk made a series of bold predictions today about the ability for his company’s cars to completely drive themselves- and Musk thinks it will happen sooner than most of his competitors — perhaps as soon as the end of this year.  A release can mean many things- and in the context of this forecast, it is assessed by the forecaster that "release" means available to the general public.  https://www.theverge.com/2019/4/22/18510828/tesla-elon-musk-autonomy-day-investor-comments-self-driving-cars-predictions.  As discussed in similar articles, the technology might be ready at the end of this year- yet only maybe for the streets next year.  https://www.usatoday.com/story/money/cars/2019/04/22/tesla-says-its-fully-self-driving-car-tech-autonomous/3540926002/.  Seeing that the developer of the technology concurs with a 0% possibility before 01 January 2020- never mind state laws http://www.ncsl.org/research/transportation/autonomous-vehicles-self-driving-vehicles-enacted-legislation.aspx.  Even today the NHTSA report that automated or “self-driving” vehicles are a future technology rather than one that you’ll find in a dealership tomorrow or in the next few years. https://www.nhtsa.gov/technology-innovation/automated-vehicles-safety.  If that is not enough, just this year, Musk admitted mistakes caused Tesla's Model 3 production delays.   http://fortune.com/2018/06/05/tesla-elon-musk-model-3-production-delay/.  Ironic he stated, “One of the biggest mistakes we made was trying to automate things that are super easy for a person to do, but really hard for a robot to do,” Musk said.  Remember, Musk is known for setting ambitious goals and timelines for the electric car company, but he isn’t known for hitting them.  Plus a recent partnership between SpaceX and NASA is going to divert development attention and resources from the navigable autopilot features. https://www.nasa.gov/spacex.  A goal’s emphasis is on the definite objective while ambition can also refer to the level of determination that is applied for the pursuit of the goal.  A goal refers to the development of the cognitive processes- while in contrast, ambition is the development of the future.   Certainly not a bad thing, but it is clear which of the two Elon Musk embodies most.
Continue to believe not quite ready (but getting closer).

Question is ambiguous, unfortunately. Not clear what "designed" and "navigate" mean here. Newest developments:
- "Tesla says that it has begun to roll out a new feature for Autopilot called Autosteer Stop Light Warning, which is included in the latest vehicle software update. The feature is as it sounds: divers using the Autosteer feature will get a warning if they’re about to run a stop light. The company says that the new safety feature is designed to help improve safe driving around stop lights, and is rolling out in a new software update, 2019.8.3. The notification pops up for drivers that are using Autosteer, and if they’re driving fast enough that they might run a red light. The feature won’t apply the car’s brakes, but it will provide a visual and audible signal that lets the driver know that they need to resume control of the car and slow down right away." [1] 
- "A Tesla hacker found a new Autopilot feature dormant in Tesla’s 2019.8.3 software update that allows the car to autonomously stop at red lights." [2] Evidence that it won't stop at recognition. "Tesla has begun producing Model X and Model S vehicles with the latest Autopilot hardware to support Full Self-Driving capabilities. Dubbed “HW3”, the new hardware is Tesla’s next iteration of its semi-autonomous driving-assist feature that includes Navigate on Autopilot, Advanced Summon, Auto Lane Change, Autopark, and the ability to respond to traffic lights." [3] The question remains whether the ability to stop at red lights is already sufficient for the question to resolve positively. I'd estimate 90% for that.
I'm also not sure what the above implies about timelines. My best guess is 80% that the feature will be rolled out before the end of the year. [1] https://www.theverge.com/2019/3/24/18279536/tesla-autosteer-stop-light-warning-autopilot-software-update-red-light
[2] https://interestingengineering.com/video/watch-tesla-autopilot-stop-at-red-lights-all-by-itself
[3] https://www.teslarati.com/tesla-autopilot-hardware-3-model-s-x/

Elon Musk's electric car Tesla has become a popular luxury car brands in the past few years, now having shipped over 300,000 vehicles across the world. Despite the hefty price tag of Model 3, X, and S cars, one of the most distinguishing features of Tesla models is the autopilot feature. At this point in time, the autopilot feature is intended solely for highway trips where a driver would not encounter traffic lights, stops or roundabouts. The company plans to expand this feature to be fully self driving capable. On December 9, 2018 Elon Musk tweeted "Already testing traffic lights, stop signs & roundabouts in development software. Your Tesla will soon be able to go from your garage at home to parking at work with no driver input at all." The company announced that these updates will be implemented "soon".  I have predicted a 5%  probability that Tesla will release an Autopilot feature designed to navigate traffic lights due to the difficulty of traffic light navigation and the time it takes to surpass legal issues regarding self-driving cars. I have no doubt that Tesla will eventually release a full Autopilot feature; however, it is highly unlikely they will do it by January 2020. Simply from Musk's tweet, it seems as though they are in the very beginning stages of the process and completion in under a year seems improbable.
I haven't had a chance to give this a listen, but I suspect it will help with this question. Putting it here as a place marker. https://ark-invest.com/research/podcast/elon-musk-podcast

tesla's self-driving technology is notably behind industry leaders and the company has received poor pr lately due to autopilot related accidents. as a result the company will be slow and careful wrt releasing advanced self-driving features in near future.

There’s a great deal of nuance in navigating traffic lights. It’s not a binary if a specific light is active but taking in complete landscape of all other traffic and actions of other drivers. For countries that allow turns on reds or have advanced/delayed greens plus pedestrians who don’t obey signals...it adds up to a great deal of processing the average slack jawed yokel handles without realizing it. Yes, it can be done, but I doubt it can be done efficiently (currently). Add in the legal aspect and maybe in remote areas but Teslas drive “everywhere”.
Just traffic lights? Easy, really the hurdle here is the governing bodies and how many people scared about "Robot Cars," lash out.
because i want to have different number from the crowd.

Yes. Elon Musk has already stated they've begun testing on traffic lights,roundabouts, and stop signs. As it stands, Teslas are only capable of operating on major highways. Adding their capability to local roads to and from the grocery store or to and from work are in high demand.

As study showed traffic light detection and interpretation is one of the toughest things in object assessment (different heights, angles, opposing sum, signs that mimic traffic lights). It is highly unlikely that autopilot will be deployable within 1yr if time.

Because current Teslas use radar for navigation and 'navigating traffic lights' will require responding to visible spectrum I am inclined to say there is literally zero chance of this happening by 1/1/2020 when the target date is 'end of 2019' in the scant evidence I can find online; I am hedging this up to 10% because the question is poorly posed by virtue of it being based on a tweet.
Musk has a long history of over promising and eventually delivering, this feature feels like it's in that category.

Hat tip to Raahul Kumar for his excellent work providing foundational information. Releasing software to recognize traffic signals is perhaps straightforward. Making good use of that information in traffic navigation is the hard part and that is not required for a YES to this question. Effective use is the difficult part and it would be very hard to tease apart from pure signal recognition. Navigation requires multiple inputs all varying over time, traffic signal recognition is just one more variable to the decision making process, NOT the decision maker.
I don't think the safety technology has been proven yet or by that timeline.

There are fifth-graders who could write the code to recognize traffic lights and respond properly to their colours, as long as the lights are functioning fully; the weather is cooperative; all other vehicles in the vicinity are being operated correctly; no emergency vehicles are coming over the hill (notably police vehicles running without sirens, as they sometimes must); and there are no other similar lights anywhere nearby to confound the sensors.   Having been driving automobiles around traffic lights since the Kennedy Administration, I estimate the probability of all this going well at maybe 70%.  This is not, presumably, good enough for Tesla to unleash these vehicles. On the other hand, the wording of the question confronts us with distinguishing between a feature "designed to" do something and a feature "effective at" doing the same thing.   Given the MuskRat's record of grandiosity, one can never be sure how this will get scored in the interval between the feature's nominal release and the attainment of an unacceptable body count.

1.Elon Musk
‏Verified account @elonmusk Already testing traffic lights, stop signs & roundabouts in development software. Your Tesla will soon be able to go from your garage at home to parking at work with no driver input at all.
https://twitter.com/elonmusk/status/1071845439140327424?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw 2. Real time traffic light detection (determining if it is red green or yellow) is a solved problem from 2017.  Self-Driving Cars: Implementing Real-Time Traffic Light Detection and Classification in 2017 Today, basic traffic light detection is a solved problem. Innovations in deep learning and computer vision exist in the form of robust algorithms. They work without developing code to manually determine the color, position, or location of the light. For example optimized R-CNN models can obtain state-of-the-art accuracy at real time speed.
https://medium.com/@anthony_sarkis/self-driving-cars-implementing-real-time-traffic-light-detection-and-classification-in-2017-7d9ae8df1c58
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=KqE0TA4whqY Traffic Light Recognition — A Visual Guide
https://medium.com/@kenan.r.alkiek/https-medium-com-kenan-r-alkiek-traffic-light-recognition-505d6ab913b1 3. Detecting traffic lights is so simple it is part of university coursework. As part of completing the second project of Udacity’s Self-Driving Car Engineer online course, I had to implement and train a deep neural network to identify German traffic signs. 
https://becominghuman.ai/deep-learning-for-traffic-signs-recognition-aead0ea7273 4. Off the shelf software and hardware works reliably to detect traffic lights.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ieVI8CehiPM 5. Firmware updates can be tracked here
https://teslafi.com/firmware/
http://ev-fw.com/track-reports.php
https://www.reddit.com/r/teslamotors/wiki/softwareupdates

It looks like this topic is still subject to extensive research and the problem of traffic light recognition not solved: https://www.researchgate.net/publication/318385033_Traffic_Light_Recognition_Exploiting_Map_and_Localization_at_Every_Stage
http://driving.stanford.edu/papers/ICRA2011.pdf
Having said that, in a sufficiently controlled environment it seems to work well enough, so there is a probability that such an Autopilot feature will be released, but only work in certain areas where digital maps are of high enough quality, or traffic lights communicate their state to the cars in their proximity. Tesla's claim to stay ahead of the curve might prompt the release of this feature even if only to support that reputation, which in turn could also boost sales and help the company turn a profit.  
One interesting aspect from this article: https://www.theverge.com/2018/5/9/17307156/google-waymo-driverless-cars-deep-learning-neural-net-interview
Comparing Waymo and Tesla: 
' “I think Tesla has the unique advantage of being able to collect data from a very wide variety of environments because there are Tesla owners with self-driving hardware all over the world,” he tells me. “This is very important for machine learning algorithms to generalize. So I would guess that at least from the data side, if not the algorithmic side, Tesla might be ahead.” ' 
At this stage, I think it is relatively likely that this feature will come this year, but not more likely to happen than not to happen.

Elon Musk's twitter statements don't seem to be the most reliable source lately. Alsoy deploying a system like this comes with quite a bit of legal and PR risk. When a car ignores a red light and causes a crash, it seems to be harder to talk oneself out of it, than when a crash happens in a situation where humans often err as well. On the other hand, the technology seems to exist in principle; the question is how much training time Tesla had and how much of a risk they are willing to take soon. With the recent layoffs, it might well be, that they will be willing to take quite a bit of risk. I give it 40% for now and correct down to 35% to account for other forecasts giving it a lower percentage.

Oh, this is a can of worms. The system has to recognise - either see a colour or get a signal from - a system which is not necessarily mounted where you expect it to be. Lights knocked off by a collision, overhead lights getting unstrung, temporary lights, lights at roadworks suspended in favour of a man with a stop-go board. Think of Las Vegas; how does it pick out red? Not only is the system non-repeating, it can fail. if the lights are stuck, a human can see the unusual pattern of traffic and adjust. If some idiot decides to jump the lights, a human can respond. In a black-out, humans can judge the over-ride. And in any legal case, death or injury at a lights system is normally regarded very seriously indeed. 
For a fully automated system to work, this has to be included, but the chance of it being legally permissible on public roads by 2020 I think is slight, and dependent mainly on Mr Musk's vanity and the ability of his legal team to think up an extraordinary defence for the first accident.

The stated aspect of any forecast is that there is a certain uncertainty about it all. This expression is particularly useful in dealing with Elon Musk. Likely to be considered one of the greatest minds of his generation, Musk is a visionary. As such, there is a high likelihood that, if he has, as stated in the question, indicated that he wants urban navigational capabilities; he will introduce said features. Whether those introduced features ever make it into an offered features list on a dealer's lot remains to be seen.

Not giving this a higher chance because it occurs to me that testing the use cases has a long tail that would eat into their revenue a lot.  That they are trying to be a profitable car company is relevant, but setting and breaking every record while publicly owned is a fraught exercise even if you are not  a severely shorted company.
By “release” I’m interpreting as available to Joe Sixpack not released as in working in one vehicle.

Good Day, oh I’m working with neural Networks and they are or go hand and hand with what is being  proposed here. Yes networks can pick out items in photograph,  facial recognition, and   Type on a letter at the post office. As far as a time actually driving a car it’s a few years away still. That’s my forecast .

I see no reason why such a feature will not be released. If it is in testing, why wouldn't it be put into production? Just because the car is able is do certain things  the driver is responsible, assessing problems and should take the wheel in the event of a problem. These kind of features is how Tesla is separating itself from other, more traditional, automakers. I think it is more likely than not.
We're talking about Tesla....NFW. This is a cult company that exists on hyperbole, bs, and government largess.

As with all matters MuskRat related, it is important to distinguish "designed to" from "able to," and "release" from "produce."   It is easy to imagine that Tesla will announce that such a feature exists and is all set to go; rather harder to imagine that it will exist in sufficient numbers of sufficient reliability for anyone other than True Believers to buy one.
